title: Sustainable Urban Art Projects
name: Sustainable Urban Art Projects
description:
A Map by Pdxnikkie

This map is intended to celebrate all the places around inner Portland that are using a wide variety of materials (mainly salvaged) to create public artworks that call our community attention to ecological sustainability. Many of these places have implemented natural building techniques and regenerative designs (such as a bioswale) into the art. Many artists chose to focus specifically on creative reuse, allowing found objects to speak the praises of sustainable art.

properties.name: Abernathy Bike Art Garden Project
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie  One of pdx\'s finest examples of public bike art (if I do say so myself). This project was a collaboration between the Community Cycling Center and the 5th Grade Class at Abernathy Elementary. Together the students, volunteers and the CCC designed, engineered and installed the Bike Art garden pieces

properties.name: Albina/Mississippi MAX Station Salvaged Metal Sculpture
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie  Wayne Chabre created symbols of the indomitable spirit of the community. A bronze, tree-like vine flowers with forms representing the arts of the area. Bronze benches incorporate images from neighborhood industries. The community map by Chabre and Jeanne McMenemy features lyrics of songs from cultures of historic importance to Albina. Works by Jacob Pander and Bill Rutherford are reproduced in porcelain enamel on steel. (text curtosy of trimet.org)

properties.name: Bike Art Fence at Big City Produce
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie  This fence is another bikey fabrication done by Matt Cartwright. The parts were originally from salvaged bicycles, as they seem. Shop for your weekly greens while you\'re in the neighborhood.

properties.name: Bike Art Sculpture at City Bikes
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie  1914 SE Ankeny St, Portland, ORA fabulous bike art sculpture looms over bikers passing by City Bikes Coop on SE Ankeny. The Sculpture stands atop the roof of the shop-with its cape flapping in the wind.

properties.name: Delta Park/Vanport MAX Station Public Art and Bioswale Project
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie   Linda Wysong addresses the area\'s layered history with an emphasis on the city of Vanport, a large wartime housing project swept away by the flood of 1948. CorTen steel sculptures recall rooftops adrift in the 1948 floodwaters. Remnants from a Vanport foundation are set into the sidewalk. A bronze railing features cast artifacts from the Chinookan culture, Vanport and the Portland International Raceway. A cast-bronze scupper channels stormwater into the bioswale below. Community maps overlay the current Delta Park site onto the city grid of Vanport, and show the location of the station within the local river systems. Works by Douglas Lynch and Timothy Scott Dalbow are reproduced in porcelain enamel on steel. Water Quality Pond Massive steel arcs allude to the engineered landscape and Liberty ships made by Vanport residents. A glowing monolith of stone, steel and acrylic symbolizes the unity of human and natural worlds.

properties.name: Ghost Bike (1)
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie  One of many of Portland\'s Ghost Bike Memorials. These ghostly painted bicycles are reminders to all those that share the road of the responsibilities we all hold to each other\'s safety. The driver at this particular site was driving under the influence alcohol and had been sited with multiple offenses previously, as well.

properties.name: Interstate/Rose Quarter Station Public Art
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie  Brian Borrello presents a three-part metaphor for displacement and change. Illuminated metal trees generate their own electricity from solar panels. A virtual campfire flickers with light at night, surrounded by stainless steel stump seats. Light filtering through colored glass on shelter roofs simulates the dappled light of a forest. Concrete tree rings in the platform symbolize the forest once abundant on the site. Custom guardrails feature branching tree limbs and roots. (text curtosy of trimet.org)

properties.name: Matthew Sheckel Lifehouse Memorial
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie  An interesting (albiet) somber spin on creative bicycle reuse. This memorial includes a prayer wheel and solar panel display.

properties.name: Metal Man (1)
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie 1438 NE Alberta St, Portland, ORThe tin shed has done well with this slavaged metal man. Its a simple, gloriously rusted, sculpture of a man sitting rigidly out front. If you\'re in the area-its worth checking out.

properties.name: N Prescott St MAX Station (yellow) Art
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie  Brian Borrello and Valerie Otani recognize the shipbuilding industry while providing an alternative approach to rainwater filtration. A stainless steel "ship\'s prow" gathers rainwater and funnels it to a greenspace. Blue glass bricks in the platform hint at imaginary waterways beneath the station. An etched granite map features Portland\'s "disappearing streams." Works by Wid Chambers and Heidi Kirkpatrick are reproduced in porcelain enamel on steel.

properties.name: Overlook Park Station Public Art
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie   Fernanda D\'Agostino was inspired by research on the healing power of light and nature. Light towers modeled after roadside shrines in Poland feature portraits of community members overlaid with images of nature. Art glass in the windscreen suggests the transforming power of nature. Community map artist Margaret Eccles created a symbol for the relationship between good health and community. (Text curtosy of trimet.org)

properties.name: River City Bike Art
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie  706 SE M L King Blvd, Portland, ORThere is a gorgeous example of found metal sculpture that incorporates bikes along the top of River City Bikes. The design was done by Matt Cartwright; many other of his works can be found on this map

properties.name: Salvaged Metal Stormwater Management Sculpture
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie 1954 SE Division St, Portland, ORHere, in front of New Season\'s is pdx/s pride and joy of stormwater management. This New Season\'s Market manages all of the property\'s storm water on site in addition to some from neighboring streets. The downspouts cascade over a found metal sculpture that\'s worth a look at.

properties.name: The Clown House
properties.description: Posted by Pdxnikkie  I\'ve been told that the owner of this imfamous pdx home mustered up enough signitures to run for mayor. Unsubstantiated-yet amusing...and man does this crowd know how to fix up a doudle-decker bicycle...or a bike jousting match...or a bike-powered lawn motor...show up for last thursday and you won\'t be disappointed
